I used to commute through the PABT and the rancid smell of the Cinnabon outlet there just nauseated me.

If I remember right, it was David Kessler who brilliantly referred to fast food as "adult baby food"--so highly processed that it's soft and squishy, with very little chewing required. That phrase has stopped me from many fast food places because it makes me think of the food they serve in nursing homes. It's probably the same basic ingredients and suppliers, only fast food gets to add a lot more salt and sugar.

But the one thing that gets me is Cinnabons. I have looked at the long list of chemicals involved and I still eat them. Just not too often.

Good thing you're not a vegan kind of guy. The 'Veggie Burger' things are generally held together with egg white (last time I looked, a chicken was neither a vegetable nor a mineral, which leaves only one category into which it could fall); and are cooked on the same grill as the meat burgers, which renders them not only greasy but nonkosher.

When I'm stuck eating fast food, I opt for a Veggie Burger at Burger King.  Just be sure to order the veggie patty.  They also offer a "veggie burger" that's just a bun with lettuce, tomato,onion and mayo.  Also, I ask for the Veggie Burger with mustard - hold the mayo.  It's actually quite good.  And I'm not a vegan kind of guy.  One disappointment - here in Southern California, BK used to offer sweet potato fries.  They were excellent, but they dropped the item.  When I asked why, I was told that there hadn't been enough demand from customers.  Too bad.

Clearly, you are an integral part of an out-of-control injustice system.  And while the injustice is certainly not all your fault, your paid participation doesn't allow you to claim innocence, either.  So stand up, shut up or get out.  Anonymous whining is pointless.
not to mention the game is fixed by Wall Street insiders who successfully manipulate the market.  So even if this sheet rock hangers learns to invest, it is still a crap shoot.

Granted the guy hanging sheet rock for 45 years cannot be expected to know investing and thus cannot be expected to guarantee his own retirement; but who will guarantee his or her retirement? The banks have failed and the government is failing by taking too much risk and taking too much debt.

One has to take the burden oneself as no one else will !

If you are skilled enough to cut and hang sheet rock competently, you should have enough brainpower to understand what you need to save and what rate of return is necessary to fund your post-working life.
To rely on this government to love you and care for you is sheer folly.

No matter, if a person can spend 45 years hanging sheet rock, that person has earned a retirement. Adding the requirement that he know how to invest as a prerequisite for retirement is nothing short of cruel.

I understand you are being largely figurative, but your perspective ignores some stark realities.

Corporations are responsible to their owners. Congress is supposed to be responsible to the voters. The healthcare lobby bought the right to force you to pay for their overpriced services because Congress was willing to sell it to them and the Supreme Court was unwilling to stop them. If the government is all powerful then the people can be expected to be surfs.

Stop condemning "Capitalism". It worked fine as long as the government was acting as a check on it through antitrust laws, etc. Capitalism is greed balanced by competition. We are getting poorer because competition is being destroyed.

If a business can go to Washington and buy lower taxes and the right to force you to buy their products or write regulations that crush their competitors, they will. This is a recent problem because the government is not supposed to have that power and did not for two centuries. The solution is to cut the government down to size so they can't sell you out!

This is not a partisan issue either. Both parties are on the corporate payroll.

We frequently hear the comment that if you're not doing anything wrong, then there's nothing to be afraid of. And yet looking at the still images of the Boston lock down, you can't help but see the frightening parallels to those scenes that Hollywood depicts in movies like The Siege. Eye-opening considering that there are other countries who actually force these same conditions on their citizens on a daily basis (and they surely didn't ask for it). We're stepping closer and closer to that invisible line that our forefathers warned us about: They who can give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety, deserve neither liberty nor safety. Does liberty really mean so little in our world today? Or are we spoiled because it was handed to us instead of us having to fight for it? Maybe we need to talk to someone in Egypt, Syria, or North Korea to get their opinion.

To Withheld from MN: Who are you hiding from that you won't use your real name while making a comment on a public forum? How's that cake tasting? BTW, I doubt if you'll get a strong consensus that our government was unequivocally elected by 100% of us. And can you really say that you will ALWAYS act with only good intentions? Intent has a way of changing with circumstances and time - not a good benchmark for laws or morality to be based upon.

@withheld...."It is only a "bad" thing if I have criminal intent..."

Here we go again with this lame argument that if your not doing something wrong you have nothing to worry about. Yet we just saw background checks for potential gun buyers get thwarted by some of you same folks.

I just don't see the difference.

How pathetically frightened and cowardly have we Americans become? I will tell you. Enough to allow ourselves to be surveilled by Big Brother on a daily basis should we venture from our homes into public places. Enough to allow our Congress pass a totally unnecessary and intrusive law like the Scoundrel . . . sorry . . . Patriot Act. Enough to spend trillions on missiles, nuclear and smart bombs, aircraft carriers, submarines, fighter and other military aircraft, tanks, artillery, landmines, and other weapons of limited and mass destruction; hundreds of thousands of men and women trained and equipped to kill on command whom we call our Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines; tens of thousands of other men and women trained to gather foreign and domestic intelligence, destabilize and overthrow foreign governments, and torture on command; trained and well armed police in every nook and cranny of this country; and public and private prisons with the largest imprisoned population in the world. Yet with all this spending on defense, intelligence and law enforcement, we still tremble with fear over a relative handful Islamic extremists, whose track record for causing death and mayhem in this country since they got lucky on 9/11 (thanks to Bush) pales into insignificance. What's even more shameful is that so-called average Americans have armed themselves to the teeth with assault rifles and a plethora of other firearms, and still they cringe in fear and welcome Big Brother's cameras.
DID YOU KNOW that 20 states and local governments and 24 universities have already been authorized by the FAA to fly drones in U.S. skies allowing them to spy, take photos and listen at will?.

In a previous response to one of Mr. Friedman's articles, I suggested that he was getting a bit rusty and ought to take time off and meditate in a Buddhist monastery. But after reading this article, I think the New York Times should oblige him to take early retirement - without a golden parachute.

In Friedman's universe, there are two types of people: innovators, who are the only people who create anything worthwhile and deserve their hugely inflated salaries, and everyone else, the drudges, who are disposable. His vision of the future bears a resemblance to the colonial regimes of the 18th and 19th centuries, in which a tiny elite of "civilized, enlightened" Europeans exploited millions of "backward, superstitious natives" and claimed it was all being done in the name of progress. Far from being new, Friedman's "401(k) World" is a very old story that is unfortunately likely to be replayed for future generations - unless we do something to stop it.

The ironic thing is that Friedman, who is telling everyone to "reinvent themselves," always writes the same thing, over and over again. Which doesn't make it more palatable.

Perhaps he should be replaced as op-ed columnist by the Dalai Lama?

At present, S$10,000 Singapore dollars is equivalent to about US$8,000.

The highest denomination banknote in Singapore is therefore equivalent to US$8,000.

What is interesting is Singapore have had S$10,000 banknotes since 1973 when the exchange rate of the one US dollar to Sing dollar is about 2.5. So back then the S10,000 note was only worth US$2,500.
The highest denomination in Singapore is $10,000. I frequently see people depositing $1,000 notes by the wads if not by the bagful at the bank tellers in Singapore.

We American seem to forget that a lot of terrorists don't care if they are caught or killed. This system will be good for deterring street crime. But to really prevent attack, you're going to have to go George Orwell and have thousands of analysts watching every movement day and night. I don't think most Americans would care for that.
